message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and findings suggest a ruptured ovarian cyst or ectopic pregnancy. Urgent surgical intervention is needed to prevent further complications such as hemorrhage and sepsis. Therefore, emergency exploratory laparotomy is the most appropriate management. Option A is for the treatment of sexually transmitted infections, option B is used to treat uterine fibroids, and option C is used in the treatment of ectopic pregnancy, but it is not appropriate in the case of rupture.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and pelvic ultrasound suggest ovarian torsion, which is a surgical emergency. Therefore, the most appropriate management is emergency exploratory laparotomy to evaluate and possibly detorse the ovary. Options A, B, and C are not appropriate for this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and ultrasound findings suggest an ovarian torsion or rupture, which requires emergency intervention. Option (D) is the correct choice as it involves surgical intervention to address the problem. Option (A) is not appropriate as the condition requires urgent treatment, and antibiotics alone will not resolve the issue. Uterine artery embolization (B) is a treatment option for uterine fibroids and abnormal uterine bleeding but is not appropriate for this patient's condition. Intravenous methotrexate administration (C) is used for medical management of ectopic pregnancy, but the negative pregnancy test and ultrasound findings make ectopic pregnancy unlikely.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of severe lower abdominal pain, a palpable tender adnexal mass, and the absence of pregnancy suggest the possibility of ovarian torsion or rupture. Emergency exploratory laparotomy is the most appropriate management for this condition. Options A, B, and C are not appropriate management for the patient's condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, physical examination, and pelvic ultrasound suggest an ovarian cyst or torsion, which can be an emergency requiring surgical intervention. Options A, B, and C are not appropriate for this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and ultrasound findings suggest a ruptured ovarian cyst or torsion, which can be life-threatening. Emergency exploratory laparotomy is necessary to evaluate and treat the situation. Oral antibiotics and methotrexate are not appropriate for this condition, and uterine artery embolization is not indicated in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, physical examination, and pelvic ultrasound findings suggest a ruptured ectopic pregnancy or ovarian torsion. Emergency exploratory laparotomy is necessary to evaluate and treat the condition, as it is the most appropriate management for a potentially life-threatening condition. Options A, B, and C are not appropriate for this clinical scenario.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest ovarian torsion or rupture, which requires immediate surgical intervention. Options (A) and (B) are not appropriate for this condition, and (C) is used for ectopic pregnancy, which has been ruled out by the negative pregnancy test.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest ovarian torsion, with imaging showing a potential ovarian mass. Emergency exploratory laparotomy is the most appropriate management in this case to prevent further damage and potential loss of the ovary. Options A, B, and C are not appropriate in this scenario.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of ovarian torsion, which can be caused by a large ovarian cyst or mass. With a palpable, tender right adnexal mass and suspected ovarian torsion, emergency exploratory laparotomy is the most appropriate management option. Oral doxycycline and metronidazole are used to treat certain infections, uterine artery embolization is used for uterine fibroids or adenomyosis, and intravenous methotrexate is used for ectopic pregnancy or gestational trophoblastic disease, but none of these conditions fit the patient's symptoms.
